title: Brexit has fueled a rise in discrimination and anxiety among immigrants, study finds
text:
Brexit has fueled a rise in discrimination among immigrants living in Britain, research has confirmed.

University College London experts looked at data taken from 300 migrants between February and October 2017.

Results showed volunteers in regions with more Leave supporters faced a sharp rise in discrimination over the seven months.

Scientists behind the study say the post-Brexit social climate is 'not only hostile, but also harmful for migrants living in the UK'.

Britain's electorate controversially voted to leave the European Union in a landmark election in June 2016.

Since then, because the country voted in favour of taking back control of the borders, concerns have been raised that migrants living in the UK have been made to feel alienated.

But lead author Dr David Frost said: 'Until now, no research had directly examined these concerns.

Migrants living in Leave areas are three times more likely to suffer anxiety after the Brexit vote according to research from UCl. Pictured: A map of how Britain voted in the 2016 referendum

'We wanted to see if there was in fact systematic evidence for these concerns by surveying migrants living across the UK using established measures.

'We found participants who lived in areas of the UK with a higher percentage of Leave voters experienced a sharper increase in discrimination over time.'

He said the findings showed this was then associated with increases in symptoms of generalised anxiety disorder.

For example, migrants living in Leave areas are around three times more likely to suffer anxiety than those in Remain areas.

Volunteers were surveyed three times, during which they were quizzed about their worries and how often they experienced discrimination.

Participants were asked to complete The Generalised Anxiety Disorder 7 (GAD7) - a scoring system made up of seven questions.

WHAT IS ANXIETY? Anxiety is a normal part of life that affects different people in different ways at different times. Whereas stress can come and go, anxiety often persists and does not always have an obvious cause. Along with depression, anxiety is among the most common mental-health condition in the UK, affecting 8.2million people in 2013 alone. Around 40million adults suffer from the condition in the US every year. Anxiety can make a person imagine things in their life are worse than they are or that they are going mad. Although it evolved as part of the 'fight or flight' mechanism in our caveman days to avoid danger, anxiety can be inappropriately activated in everyday life when stress builds up. It can have a clear cause, such as moving house or having surgery. However, sometimes little life events build up until a person is unable to cope, with anxiety then taking them by surprise. Physical symptoms can include: Increased heart rate and muscle tension

Hyperventilation and dizziness

Nausea

A tight band across the chest

Tension headaches

Hot flushes

Sweating

'Jelly legs'

Shaking

Feeling like you are choking

Tingling in the hands and feet Some psychological symptoms are: Thinking you are going mad or losing control

Thinking you may die or get ill

Feeling people are staring at you

Feeling detached from others or on edge Treatment often involves counselling or cognitive behavioural therapy. Activates like yoga, exercise, reading and socialising can help to manage anxiety.

They are quizzed on their mood and how easy they find it to relax. Response options include 'not at all', 'several days', 'more than half the days' and 'nearly every day'.

Scores of five, 10, and 15 represent mild, moderate, and severe anxiety, respectively.

Volunteers were also asked separately about how often they experienced nine types of discrimination at three points during 2017.

These ranged from being treated with less courtesy to being harassed.

Data was cross-referenced with voting records from their local areas, obtained from the UK Electoral Commission.

It showed there was a three-fold increase in the number of symptoms of clinical anxiety in areas with a strong Leave presence.

The findings held true when other factors associated with discrimination and anxiety were accounted for, including ethnicity and age.

Migrants from the US, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand were excluded because they experience privileged status in the UK.

Dr Frost added: 'These findings indicate that the post-Brexit social climate is not only hostile, but also harmful for migrants living in the UK.

'Politicians, community leaders, and health professionals all need to be more aware of how the Brexit debate has impacted the lives of migrants in the UK in order to take steps to improve the social climate and address its negative effects on their well-being.'

Anxiety affects around eight million people in the UK. Around 40million adults suffer from the condition in the US.

The findings were published in the American Psychological Association's Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology.

The study comes after doctors revealed a father had become the first person to suffer from Brexit-triggered psychosis last month.

The patient, in his forties and from Nottingham, was so ill following the referendum he tried to burrow out of hospital with his bare hands.

He even feared that one of his wife's relatives was going to shoot him with a heat-seeking missile, and heard voices in his head.

The patient was increasingly worried about racial incidents and said he was ashamed to be British following the 2016 poll.
description: Researchers from University College London looked at 300 migrants living in Britain between February and October 2017 - seven months after the referendum.
authors: Connor Boyd Health Reporter For Mailonline
